description: Hyper-V is the advanced virtualization platform created by Microsoft. It is a fully featured Type 1 hypervisor capable of supporting environments ranging from small businesses with a single server to massive datacenters containing thousands of servers. This skills series covers installing, managing and maintaining Hyper-V.

virtual machines is what we're gonna do,

Second one's gonna be a basic VM but

to show you how powerful

And why we might need to do that as well.

00:02:13,730 --> 00:02:15,470

38

One on the client side, Hyper-V, and

39

where are we gonna start today?

40
00:02:22,810 --> 00:02:26,090
>> I think we'll just start with

00:02:26,090 --> 00:02:26,980
>> All right, sounds great.

>> So we'll do it on the client side,

00:02:28,870 --> 00:02:31,370

And we'll make one up, and
do like you said, the advanced.

45
00:02:35,290 --> 00:02:39,750
Well, maybe not advanced,
more customized one on the server.

46
00:02:39,750 --> 00:02:40,850
>> Sounds great!

47
00:02:40,850 --> 00:02:44,490
>> All right so
kicking off on this machine here.

48
00:02:44,490 --> 00:02:46,770
Let's jump into Hyper-V Manager.

49

50
00:02:53,510 --> 00:02:56,330
And there we go so
now it should be familiar to us now.

51
00:02:56,330 --> 00:03:00,699
So we kinda have an idea of where we need
to go to click on things, to do stuff.

52
00:03:01,710 --> 00:03:05,360
And so
to get started over in our actions pane,

53
00:03:05,360 --> 00:03:08,800
we will click on new cuz we want
to create a new virtual machine.

54
00:03:10,790 --> 00:03:12,730
And in our wizard here.

55
00:03:12,730 --> 00:03:15,140
So, this wizard helps you
create a new virtual machine.

56
00:03:15,140 --> 00:03:16,715
Sweet.
So we are on the right track.

57
00:03:16,715 --> 00:03:18,560
>> [LAUGH] Yes, we are.

58
00:03:18,560 --> 00:03:23,950
>> We will click on next and now we
need to give our virtual machine a name.

59
00:03:23,950 --> 00:03:26,690
Now, this isn't the computer name.

60
00:03:26,690 --> 00:03:30,400
So, after we've installed Windows or
whatever it is that we're going to install

61
00:03:30,400 --> 00:03:35,540
on here, we can't install certain
Linux distros and other things.

62
00:03:35,540 --> 00:03:41,200
So this is just the name to identify
this machine inside Hyper-V manager.

63
00:03:41,200 --> 00:03:42,010
>> Right.

64
00:03:42,010 --> 00:03:46,409
>> So generally I like to name it
something that is descriptive to

65
00:03:46,409 --> 00:03:49,128
whatever it is I'm installing on it.

66
00:03:49,128 --> 00:03:54,170
So this one we're just going to
call Windows 8.1 so Windows 8.1.

67
00:03:54,170 --> 00:03:55,795
>> Okay, sounds good.

68
00:03:55,795 --> 00:03:59,550
>> All right, now what we can do is store
the machine in a different location.

69
00:03:59,550 --> 00:04:03,979
Now our default location down there
in the gray is in ProgramData,

70
00:04:03,979 --> 00:04:06,045
Microsoft Windows Hyper-V.

71
00:04:06,045 --> 00:04:10,686
That ProgramData's a hidden folder, so
just browse around in your hard drive,

72
00:04:10,686 --> 00:04:12,400
you will not see this folder.

73
00:04:12,400 --> 00:04:13,928
Well, unless you choose
show hidden folders.

74
00:04:13,928 --> 00:04:18,700
But yeah, so
kind of a buried location here.

75
00:04:18,700 --> 00:04:24,300
So for us, what I will do is I'll choose
to store it in a different location.

76
00:04:25,910 --> 00:04:30,098
My favorite folder called Virtuals and
we'll just leave that Hyper-V,

77
00:04:30,098 --> 00:04:31,120
that works well.

78
00:04:32,210 --> 00:04:33,837
All right, and next.

79
00:04:33,837 --> 00:04:35,336
>> Oh, a couple of options.

80
00:04:35,336 --> 00:04:36,200
>> A couple of options here.

81
00:04:36,200 --> 00:04:40,730
So we have two different
generations of machines.

82
00:04:40,730 --> 00:04:41,520
Generation 1, so

83
00:04:41,520 --> 00:04:46,390
this would be for our older operating
systems, those sorts of things.

84
00:04:46,390 --> 00:04:51,710
Generation 2 as a little wizard there says
that we have things like Secure Boot,

85
00:04:51,710 --> 00:04:56,870
which Secure Boot, it, I guess,
verifies that the boot process,

86
00:04:56,870 --> 00:05:01,850
nothing has been tampered with and if it
has, then Windows will refuse to boot up.

87
00:05:01,850 --> 00:05:04,050
It will throw out an error.

88
00:05:04,050 --> 00:05:05,740
We have SCSI Boot, which is good and

89
00:05:05,740 --> 00:05:08,720
then PXE Booting using
a standard network adapter.

90
00:05:08,720 --> 00:05:12,780
Now if we had a generation, well you
know what, should we create one of each?

91
00:05:13,810 --> 00:05:15,180
Generation 1 and Generation 2?

92
00:05:15,180 --> 00:05:16,130
>> Sure why not.

93
00:05:16,130 --> 00:05:16,900
>> Right?

94
00:05:16,900 --> 00:05:17,610
Okay.

95
00:05:17,610 --> 00:05:21,770
So we'll do Windows 8.1,
we'll just use the same operating system.

96
00:05:21,770 --> 00:05:24,525
On this one,
we'll just do a standard Generation 1.

97
00:05:25,920 --> 00:05:28,090
And click on,
well I guess to finish with that thought.

98
00:05:28,090 --> 00:05:28,620
>> Yeah.

99
00:05:28,620 --> 00:05:32,620
>> So with a Generation 1,
if we want PXE boot a machine, so

100
00:05:32,620 --> 00:05:36,560
if we want to boot this machine up and
discover a.

101
00:05:38,060 --> 00:05:38,980
>> Deployment server.

102
00:05:38,980 --> 00:05:41,100
>> Yeah.
>> Or a yep, PXE driver.

103
00:05:41,100 --> 00:05:42,260
>> Good.
You wanna go ahead and

104
00:05:42,260 --> 00:05:43,840
explain PXE boot then?

105
00:05:43,840 --> 00:05:45,218
>> Nope go ahead.

106
00:05:45,218 --> 00:05:49,700
>> No, I'm okay so for it to discover
a deployment server out there that is

107
00:05:49,700 --> 00:05:54,900
hosting an operating system,
or an image of one.

108
00:05:54,900 --> 00:05:59,650
That it will automatically connect to that
deployment server and pull down an image.

109
00:05:59,650 --> 00:06:02,450
And is install itself on there.

110
00:06:02,450 --> 00:06:07,140
So on a Generation 1,
we had to have legacy network adapter.

111
00:06:07,140 --> 00:06:09,370
Which we'll see when we get
into the virtual switches.

112
00:06:09,370 --> 00:06:11,740
But on the Generation 2, we don't need it.

113
00:06:11,740 --> 00:06:14,300
We can use the standard network adapter.

114
00:06:14,300 --> 00:06:18,550
The standard network adapters will have
faster speeds, better throughput or

115
00:06:18,550 --> 00:06:22,865
lower latency than the legacy network
adapters in the Generation 1.

116
00:06:24,020 --> 00:06:28,340
So, for us, we'll just choose
a Generation 1, click on next.

117
00:06:28,340 --> 00:06:31,900
So, now we get to specify how
much memory this machine has.

118
00:06:31,900 --> 00:06:34,910
Now it says startup memory,
so how much memory,

119
00:06:34,910 --> 00:06:38,590
it will grab initially as
this machine spins up.

120
00:06:40,610 --> 00:06:43,380
If we choose this option here,
use dynamic memory,

121
00:06:43,380 --> 00:06:48,260
the virtual machine it will
collect more RAM as it needs it.

122
00:06:48,260 --> 00:06:52,857
So if we're running some kind
of tasks on it, it will call and

123
00:06:52,857 --> 00:06:56,295
say hey, I need additional RAM and
it get it.

124
00:06:56,295 --> 00:06:59,820
But then when the machine idles down,
it can release that RAM.

125
00:07:01,210 --> 00:07:05,550
So, if we do not choose this option
then whatever the startup memory is,

126
00:07:05,550 --> 00:07:06,660
is what it's going to get.

127
00:07:06,660 --> 00:07:08,500
No more and no less.

128
00:07:08,500 --> 00:07:11,420
We choose dynamic memory,
then it can fluctuate, but

129
00:07:11,420 --> 00:07:14,570
it will take this memory
initially as it spins up.

130
00:07:15,960 --> 00:07:19,700
So what we will do,
we will use dynamic memory for us.

131
00:07:19,700 --> 00:07:24,590
And we will give this machine 2
GB of memory for it to start up.

132
00:07:24,590 --> 00:07:26,840
>> Very nice.
>> Of course, after it's installed and

133
00:07:26,840 --> 00:07:30,730
after the guy idles up, or idles down?

134
00:07:30,730 --> 00:07:32,500
It should release some memory back.

135
00:07:34,830 --> 00:07:37,990
All right so here we get to
choose our network connection.

136
00:07:37,990 --> 00:07:41,640
All right now we don't have
any virtual switches created.

137
00:07:41,640 --> 00:07:46,096
Now, we will go through creating virtual
switches and network adapters, or

138
00:07:46,096 --> 00:07:50,153
not network adapters, just the virtual
switches on the server side.

139
00:07:50,153 --> 00:07:55,569
And the reason being is On this PC here
we're doing the screen sharing software.

140
00:07:55,569 --> 00:07:57,987
And if I create these virtual switches,

141
00:07:57,987 --> 00:08:01,390
then it's going to reconfigure
the network adapters.

142
00:08:01,390 --> 00:08:04,360
In the past,
it has played havoc with our screen share.

143
00:08:04,360 --> 00:08:07,505
So we will cover this when
we get to the service side.

144
00:08:07,505 --> 00:08:14,480
So we won't connect it to any networks,
and now we get into virtual hard disks.

145
00:08:14,480 --> 00:08:15,545
Now virtual hard disks,

146
00:08:15,545 --> 00:08:20,250
there's a bit more configuration
than just this little menu here.

147
00:08:20,250 --> 00:08:25,520
We can create a basic one,
right here on a VHDX format,

148
00:08:26,600 --> 00:08:30,010
in this location with this size.

149
00:08:30,010 --> 00:08:32,350
If we had an existing virtual hard drive,

150
00:08:32,350 --> 00:08:36,500
let's say we had to destroy the VM for
some reason.

151
00:08:36,500 --> 00:08:41,930
And we're creating a new VM, and we
wanted to use an older hard drive, right?

152
00:08:41,930 --> 00:08:46,990
We can choose that option there, but what
we will do is choose to attach one later.

153
00:08:49,090 --> 00:08:52,260
And then our little screen here.

154
00:08:52,260 --> 00:08:55,130
And we'll click on finish, all right.

155
00:08:56,220 --> 00:08:56,940
There we go.

156
00:08:56,940 --> 00:08:59,050
So there's our virtual machine.

157
00:08:59,050 --> 00:09:00,010
>> Yeah.

158
00:09:00,010 --> 00:09:03,621
Yeah, on the basic VM, right, what we're
doing is we're simply walking through

159
00:09:03,621 --> 00:09:06,520
the menu a lot of times and
just selecting the most basic function.

160
00:09:06,520 --> 00:09:09,300
Now, Nate went even more basic than that,
because we wanted to show you each and

161
00:09:09,300 --> 00:09:10,810
every one of those details.

162
00:09:10,810 --> 00:09:12,270
What you can do to actually,

163
00:09:12,270 --> 00:09:16,270
again, choose what you'd rather do
instead of just accepting the defaults.

164
00:09:16,270 --> 00:09:20,142
So right now, we've got a virtual machine,
Nate, with no hard hard drive.

165
00:09:20,142 --> 00:09:21,840
>> [LAUGH]
>> Mm-hm.

166
00:09:21,840 --> 00:09:24,110
>> With some Ram assigned, but

167
00:09:24,110 --> 00:09:26,610
no operating system actually
installed on there.

168
00:09:26,610 --> 00:09:30,580
So we have a listing of a virtual machine,
but really nothing on it.

169
00:09:30,580 --> 00:09:32,380
So, what's our next step, Nate?

170
00:09:32,380 --> 00:09:33,140
>> Our next step here,

171
00:09:33,140 --> 00:09:38,060
right now, I believe what we can do is
create that virtual hard drive, and

172
00:09:38,060 --> 00:09:42,650
assign this virtual hard drive to this PC,
and begin installing an operating system.

173
00:09:42,650 --> 00:09:43,182
>> Sounds good.

174
00:09:43,182 --> 00:09:43,921
>> All right.

175
00:09:43,921 --> 00:09:48,453
But I think, Ronnie, before we do that,
let's quickly we'll run through this, and

176
00:09:48,453 --> 00:09:50,760
let's create that Generation 2 machine.

177
00:09:50,760 --> 00:09:52,060
>> All right, let's do it.

178
00:09:52,060 --> 00:09:53,660
>> All right, so
this menu we've seen this before.

179
00:09:53,660 --> 00:09:54,550
We'll just create that.

180
00:09:54,550 --> 00:10:01,250
So we'll call this one 181GEN2.

181
00:10:01,250 --> 00:10:03,120
We will store it in a different location.

182
00:10:03,120 --> 00:10:10,376
And we'll choose to store
this our our Virtuals.

183
00:10:10,376 --> 00:10:15,110
Hyper-V folder, and Next.

184
00:10:15,110 --> 00:10:17,550
This will be a Generation 2.

185
00:10:17,550 --> 00:10:22,110
Now, in Generation 2, as we can
see here at the bottom, the guest

00:10:22,110 --> 00:10:27,850
operating system, whatever is going to
be installed on this virtual machine

187
00:10:27,850 --> 00:10:33,490
needs to be either Windows Server 2012,
or Windows 8, or higher.

188
00:10:33,490 --> 00:10:35,796
So we're going to throw on 8.1,
which works.

00:10:35,796 --> 00:10:41,356

00:10:41,356 --> 00:10:44,630

a Windows 7 machine,
